docs.lead_paragraph: Once again, a tug-of-war over abortion is dividing the Republican Party, and two developments in California this week underscore the strains. Top Republican officials converged at this community of spas and golf courses near Palm Springs today for the party's winter meeting with the chief goal of defeating a resolution to withhold party money to candidates who oppose banning late-term abortions. Most prominent Republicans, even foes of abortion, have avoided the controversy or denounced the resolution as at odds with efforts to broaden the party.

headline.main: Late-Term Abortion Issue Pulls Republicans in Two Directions

docs.abstract: Abortion issue once again roils Republican party, as leaders gather for winter meeting with chief goal of defeating resolution to withhold party funds from candidates who oppose ban on late-term abortions; split is likely to widen even if resolution fails, particularly now that conservative Tom J Bordonaro has placed ahead of moderate Brooks Firestone in special House election in California; party leaders Newt Gingrich and Trent Lott restate support for ban on late-term abortion, but do not mention resolution; even Dan Quayle privately urges measure's defeat (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Shifting Certainties in the Abortion War'' (Week in Review, Jan. 11) says that morning-after pills end pregnancies. In fact, emergency contraceptive pills -- which can be used before the morning after and up to 72 hours after unprotected intercourse -- do not interrupt an established pregnancy. By preventing pregnancy, they reduce the need for abortion. Making emergency contraceptive pills widely available is one of the most important steps we can take to reduce the unacceptable incidence of unintended pregnancy in the United States (3.2 million a year). For women to avail themselves of this contraceptive option, they must be informed that ordinary birth control pills can be taken in higher than usual doses after unprotected intercourse to prevent pregnancy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years and nearly 30 million abortions after the Supreme Court's landmark Roe v. Wade decision, the American public still largely supports legalized abortion but says it should be harder to get and less readily chosen, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. At base, the country remains irreconcilably riven over what many consider the most divisive American issue since slavery, with half the population considering abortion murder, the poll found. Despite a quarter-century of lobbying, debating and protesting by the camps that call themselves ''pro-choice'' and ''pro-life,'' that schism has remained virtually unaltered.

headline.main: Public Still Backs Abortion, But Wants Limits, Poll Says

docs.abstract: New York Times/CBS News Poll finds that, 25 years after Supreme Court's landmark ruling, Americans still largely support legalized abortion, but believe it should be harder to get and less readily chosen; finds that basic schism between 'pro-life' and 'pro-choice' remains virtually unaltered, but public opinion has shifted notably away from general acceptance of legal abortion toward more nuanced, conditional acceptance, or 'permit but discourage'; 61 percent of those polled believe abortion should be permitted in first three months of pregnancy, but approval plummets to 15 percent in second trimester and seven percent in last trimester; support declines for reasons like interruption of career or education, but remains overwhelming in cases or rape, endangered health or likely birth defects; graphs showing sometimes paradoxical responses; analyst Dr Elizabeth Adell Cook sees public agreeing with Pres Clinton that abortion should be 'safe, legal and rare,' allowable but not taken lightly (L)
